div1.p: Hamer writes about his sickness resulting from a bad tooth. He also discusses the impossibility of women visiting.

As you know that I am sick and in the Hospital. I would suppose that you are anxious to hear from me how I am getting and so on. Well I cannot say that I am much better than I was when I wrote to you last although I beleive I am a little better. I have still a pain in the side of my head - somewhat like a neuralgia. I think it arises from a bad tooth which must be extricated if it dont behave. I had, also a pain on the breast but I had a blistering plaster, - a terrible hot one, too it burnt a little lik Greek fire - laid on my breast and that put a stop to that. I am not confined to bed and when the weather permits I can run about through town. Emanuel Carster is in the hospital, too.

I received a letter from Eveline the other day. Tell her Ill write as soon as I get a little better. She said she soon be at home again. If my old red shirt is pretty good yet and you get a good chance suppose you send it down Maybe Nathaniel will take a notion to come down and bring me a Christmas gift. I wish he only could or poor us will have to do without a Christmas again. I would not invite any women down here because you could not get a place to stay over night among so many sesh.

I would like if somebody would see after that money that I sent with Joseph Spangler ($60.00) and let me know as soon as possable if it arrived safely. If it is not at Raineys or Pisels some one had better go over to Spanglers and get it.
I hope to be able to go back to camp in a few days altho my medicin keeps me middling weak.
Give my well wishes to my dear parents, brothers and Sisters. Write soon.

closer.salute:
I still remain your most affectionate
Brother
closer.seg: I wrote to you on the 19th Mary Ann Hamer
